Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Bioconversion of Agricultural Waste Residue into Value-added Manufacturing Chemicals
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stereolithography and 3-D printing are examples of emerging technologies that are revolutionizing prototyping and manufacturing. These technologies not only allow consumers to fabricate custom products on demand but also present ways for the military, NASA, medical providers and others to solve problems in the field. These rapid fabrication procedures employ polymer materials which are typically generated from petroleum. As these technologies become more commonplace it will be important to find alternative and sustainable ways to produce the input materials required. This I-Corps proposal is designed to analyze the market potential for manufacturing polymers generated from agricultural waste residues.

This I-Corps proposal is designed to analyze the market potential for manufacturing polymers generated by microbial biocatalysts from agricultural waste residues. Research by others and the team has revealed unique metabolic capabilities of non-traditional yeast. The team has identified pathways that will allow a percentage of the metabolic flux to be diverted to produce specific high value polymers. The proposed technology platform, which is built around abundant monomers and takes advantage of readily available inexpensive substrates, has potential for cost-effective production of value added chemicals and materials. The technology developed by the team will expand the understanding of how environmental resources can be better used.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our University of Wisconsin team (Phoenix AgriChem) was awarded a grant from the National Science Foundation to participate in the Innovation Corps (I-Corps) program. We're biological engineers with experience using microbes such as yeast to turn lower value materials (like corn stalks) into higher value products. The goal of this I-Corps project was to assess the commercial potential for a bioconversion technology that could turn agricultural waste residues into bio-based manufacturing polymers that would 1) be sustainable and 2) serve as a substitute for petroleum-based chemicals. It?s sort of a "spin straw into gold" approach, if you will.

At the beginning of the I-Corps program our primary concern was identifying which of the materials and chemicals we can manufacture would be profitable and in what market. To figure that out, over a six week span our three-person team interviewed more than a hundred people worldwide to learn about the unmet needs of these potential customers and business partners, and to test our hypotheses about the commercial potential of our technology. Although we initially thought that customers would be interested in sustainable sources of polymers for 3D printing and other types of additive manufacturing, our hypothesis was not supported by the information we gained from the interviews. We learned that reduced environmental impact is not a "must have" for additive manufacturing users.

We pivoted to look at product market fit for the injection molding and packaging markets. Our interviews revealed that while our products could fit into commodities markets, US customers are only attracted to the concept of reduced environmental impact until they see the bottom line. Higher costs associated with production of biobased materials meant that our initial ideas would not fit the needs of this market. We also explored Europe as a market, but while the people we spoke with expressed an increased interest in our product?s sustainability, they were concerned about the use genetically modified organisms in our process. Our findings from the interviews indicated that production of commodity products using our technology has little potential for commercialization in the near future. At this point our team has decided our product is a no go if we sell it as a commodity. Using the tools we learned in I-Corps, we will next explore whether there is a market need for one of our specialty formulations in an industry such as consumer products and cosmetics.

One broader impact of our technology is the potential to benefit society by identifying applications for renewable and sustainable manufacturing or specialty materials. The production of biobased materials could decrease U.S. dependence on foreign oil, which would in turn contribute to improved domestic security and reduced environmental impact. Furthermore, as an all women team, this project increased the participation and visibility of women in STEM industries. This I-Corps project resulted in increased contact and potential partnerships between academia and industry. Additionally, the principal investigator on the project has incorporated some of the Lean Startup methodologies and business model canvas into their research program, with an emphasis on earlier evaluation of commercial potential of research projects.

 


Last Modified: 11/14/2019
Modified by: Laura B Willis
